question: In what unit is the distance between the Sun and Proxima Centauri most accurately measured?

content.source_1: In general-audience astronomy, distances between stars are commonly expressed in light-years—the distance light travels in one year, about 9.46×10^12 kilometers.
content.source_2: Introductory references typically state that Proxima Centauri is about 4.24 light-years from the Sun.
content.source_3: A parsec (pc) is defined so that a star at 1 pc shows a trigonometric parallax of 1 arcsecond; parallax is the fundamental geometric method for measuring distances to nearby stars.
content.source_4: Gaia-based astrometric catalogs publish stellar parallaxes in milliarcseconds and provide derived distance estimates (with uncertainties) in parsecs.
content.source_5: Converting parsec distances to light-years is a fixed scaling (1 pc ≈ 3.26156 ly), and popular summaries often round the light-year value for readability.
content.source_6: Professional research papers and nearby-star catalogs typically report distances and their error bars in parsecs rather than in light-years.
